Section 4 Analysis 1 4.1 Adoption of new technologies When it comes to the generation of new technologies, economies can either create these themselves or import them. It has been widely established in economic research that the latter is more common.17 Consequently, it makes sense to investigate the trade dynamics between economies, i.e. import and export flows. Different speeds and intensities of technology adoption across countries and over time can be highlighted this way. However, it must be stressed that the mere adoption of new technologies through importation does not guarantee the local absorption and diffusion. For this to be a successful strategy, preconditions that create a growth-enabling environment of a country matter:18 The most recent Industrial Development Report (UNIDO 2020) also focuses on industry 4.0 with new firm level data. It stresses the necessity of certain pre-requisites in order for firms being able to successfully adopt new (digital) technology. They range from institutional and infrastructure capabilities such as energy supply and connectivity, to production and technological capabilities such as skilled staff that can handle machines and software, to changes in a firm’s culture such as the acceptance of more automation in the production process. Importing technology can additionally strengthen these capabilities as there are learning processes related to trade. These can come from cooperation with universities or foreign partners, or from reverse engineering, just to name a few. For the purpose of the analysis of this tool a heterogeneous group of countries is considered. This group consists of a set of advanced economies (Germany, Japan and the Republic of Korea), all of which are big players in the adoption and generation of new technologies; see Appendix A. The list of countries is complemented by a group of emerging economies (China, the Russian Federation as well as Viet Nam and Georgia). These countries have been selected with the purpose to illustrate particular development patterns observed in the adoption strategies of industry 4.0 technologies. As we have seen in the previous discussion, industry 4.0 technologies are a sub-group of capital goods. Whereas the former identify cutting-edge technologies one is most likely to find in modern, state-of-the-art manufacturing facilities, capital goods cover a much broader domain. Capital goods are machinery and other manufactured goods which are used by industry, government and non-profit private institutions. They are in fact producers’ goods that are defined as part of fixed capital formation (United Nations Trade Statistics 2003). Capital goods form one of the central building blocks of a healthy and growing manufacturing sector: Economic research has demonstrated that manufacturing provides great potential for positive growth trajectories through its scalability and high degree of capital accumulation, both of which can be identified through the utilisation of capital goods. Consequently, the analysis begins on the level of the capital goods group which can be understood to represent both the latest as well as already more established production technologies. Then, the same tools are applied for the sub-group of industry 4.0 goods that allow to identify industry 4.0-specific dynamics.This is done with the goal to provide a simple tool for policy makers to analyse and categorise where their own economy stands relative to other economies and the global level, both in the utilisation of capital goods as well as industry 4.0 technology as part of the domestic production process. It will become clear that different income groups of countries (high income, upper-middle income, lower-middle income and low income) show some distinct trade patterns when it comes to imports and exports of production technology. 4.1.1 Capital goods The first graph (Figure 4.1) shows shares of imports of capital goods in all goods (indicator 3.1) between 2002 and 2017. Considering the whole time period, only the Russian Federation increased its import share significantly. What might be surprising, is that there is no clear division between high-income countries and the others. For example, Japan as well as Georgia had decreasing shares until the middle of the last decade when shares started to increase again. On the one hand, decreasing import shares can mean that relatively fewer capital goods are imported because a country is able to produce them domestically. On the other hand, increasing import shares can show that a country is increasingly able to use goods that are related to some technology. Figure 4.1: Share of capital goods imports in total imports While imports can highlight users of production technologies, exports show producers (indicator 3.2). Figure 4.2: Share of capital goods exports in total exports Figure 4.2 makes clear that there are countries such as Japan, the Republic of Korea, Germany or China where capital goods make up one third of their total exports, while others such as the Russian Federation or Georgia decreased their shares of capital goods in exports. Viet Nam seems to have transformed into an exporter in the last ten to fifteen years. Since the numbers represent production technology of all vintages, we cannot yet see who the technology leaders are in terms of new technological advancements. This will be done by inspecting imports and exports of 4.0 goods below. An immediate question arising from this initial analysis is how policy makers can obtain a benchmark relating country performance patterns to global dynamics. We propose two indicators to facilitate this requirement: By calculating the import shares relative to the world average (indicator 3.3), one can quantify the import performance of a country in relation to the global average. This relation is called ‘revealed comparative advantage’ (RCA). If a country is characterized by an import RCA larger than one, this means that it imports more than the world average. In turn, this could point to a faster adoption of technology for countries that are not yet at the technological frontier. In that sense, the RCA of imports (indicator 3.3) is strongly connected to the adoption rate (indicator 3.1) as both indicators depend on the share of capital goods in total imports. The same overall import profiles will show across countries with both indicators but the interpretation changes as RCA is a relative measure. As the second indicator, RCA exports (indicator 3.4), serves as a key measure to detect the local capabilities of countries in producing capital goods. As before, if a country is characterized by an RCA (export) larger than 1, it exports more than the global average. This means that it has acquired capabilities to export sophisticated and technology-intensive goods and is competitive on the global stage. Figure 4.3: Revealed comparative advantage, imports and exports of capital goods An interesting picture emerges from the figure above. Figure 4.3 displays if countries import or export more or less than the world average. When this information is combined, a story about technology adoption that is based on ‘revealed’ trade flows can be told. Let us look at examples to make this clear: The Russian Federation is the only country in our sample that clearly imports more capital goods over time than the world average (upper graph); while it also exports much less than the world average (lower graph). This points to the fact that the Russian Federation uses capital goods and technologies that come with them in their production process but they are not above-average exporters. This is either because (i) they have not yet adopted and absorbed the technology to an extent that allows them to become exporters of capital goods or (ii) they produce only for the domestic market or (iii) they use the production technology to produce and export other (non-capital) goods. Similar to the Russian Federation, Georgia shows low export exposure compared to the world average. However, they also do not import significantly more capital goods than the world average. This most likely points to the fact that Georgia is not yet able to adopt all the technologies that are associated with capital goods. The rest of the countries show a relatively similar evolution. Over time, they import less capital goods than the world average. While China decreased its share continuously, the others are relatively stable across the years. At the same time, they export more than the world average. This implies that these countries have to produce capital goods themselves. This is another indicator of successful technology adoption, in the sense that they no longer need to import production technology but have become producers. On the basis of the indicators shown we can create a classification of the following sort. RCA import RCA export Group < 1 > 1 specialized producer > 1 > 1 specialized producer and user > 1 < 1 specialized user < 1 < 1 non-specialized Here, ‘specialized producer’ indicates a country with an import RCA of below (or close to) one and an export RCA greater than one. These countries have a revealed comparative advantage in exporting goods (but not in importing) and are typically the ones closest to the technology frontier. Next up are economies which are ‘specialized producers and users’ which have a comparative advantage in both importing and in exporting. Here it is important to emphasise that, despite the fact that they have an import and export RCA greater than one, most likely they do not import the same set of goods as they export. This means that if such a country is identified for, say, capital goods, it makes sense to ‘dig deeper’ and look at what kind of capital goods the country imports and exports. Most likely this is where some differences can be identified: A country may be a strong exporter for some groups of goods, while it may still be an importer when it comes to the adoption of the latest available technology. We can see this through the analysis of RCAs of industry 4.0 goods below. China is an example that, in the beginning of the period, showed a pattern as described but continuously decreased its share in capital goods imports. The third group, which consists of ‘specialized users’, are countries with an import RCA bigger than one and an export RCA smaller than one. These are the countries that typically try to adopt new technology through imports and absorption. The Russian Federation is an example in our sample. Lastly, with both RCAs below one, these countries are non-specialized, at least not yet. This classification of countries based on trade flows of capital goods can help policy makers, first, to evaluate if they are users or producers of production technology. Second, it can act as a benchmarking exercise in technology adoption because the classification is very much related to income groups defined by the World Bank (2019). Figure 4.4 illustrates very clearly that, on average, there is a considerable spread for the export RCAs of capital goods: High income countries have on average the highest export RCAs, followed by upper middle, lower middle and finally low income countries. As for import RCAs, we can observe that, on average, the import propensity seems to first build up as economies grow richer but decline after a country has reached the lower middle income mark. It has to be noted, however, that for all four income group aggregates, the differences are both relatively small in terms of magnitude and also well centred around the global average mark of ‘1’. Figure 4.4: RCA exports and imports for capital goods by income group For capital goods, which represent all forms of production technology, this means that the higher the income of a country, the more likely it is to be an exporter of these goods. Overall, only a relatively small fraction of countries are specialized exporters but around half of countries are specialized importers and thus users of capital goods. For more details, see Appendix I Disclaimer to classification Please note that this analysis provides a simplified means to analyse an otherwise very complex topic and any obtained classification of a particular country and year should always be considered with a grain of salt: Good knowledge of the country’s particular situation as well as the time profile of the RCAs is recommended. This is because of the following reasons. ‘Revealed’ trade patterns are used to infer adoption rates from that. Some countries, such as the United States have a large domestic market. Their share of exports of high-technology goods in their total exports might be relatively small, although the U.S. can clearly be considered a technology leader. The cut-off at ‘1’ tells a clear story in that it represents the world average of import or export shares; however, some countries might be very close to that cut-off, being above it and then below it in the next year. Especially small product groups might show high volatility (fluctuations) in the numbers resulting possibly in a misleading story. To get a complete picture, always look at the whole time series of your country of interest and also take other country specific information, you might have, into account. In our example, China and Viet Nam changed the group over the years which is an important information about their development. What is more, the exercise of calculating RCAs could alternatively be done with imports and exports as shares of nominal gross domestic product. This variant leads to very similar results as the one presented above. Also, using ‘1’ as the relevant cut-off to define the classification could be replaced by using the average of all country RCAs in imports and exports respectively. We propose to use ‘1’ as cut-off as it is simpler and does not change the main insights discussed above qualitatively when using the averages instead. 4.1.2 Adoption of industry 4.0 technologies While the numbers above concerned all capital goods, the focus now switches to 4.0 goods, goods related to additive manufacturing, CAD-CAM or robotics which are part of the ‘smart factory’. With the same method as above, it can be found out which countries are users and producers of goods related to the latest technological production processes. The following graph (Figure 4.5) shows the share of imports of 4.0 goods in total imports in percent (indicator 3.5). First, the numbers for some of the countries in the sub-sample are remarkably stable over time and they are still relatively low in absolute terms, as the smart factory is a relatively new phenomenon. We know from other research (see e.g., Lavopa (2019) or Gal et al. (2019)) that it is a small number of mostly highly productive firms that are the first that adopt new technologies generating a ‘digital capability gap’ within countries between the ‘best and the rest’. During the first decade of the century, the Russian Federation, China and Viet Nam decreased their share of imports of 4.0 goods. Beginning in 2010, with the exception of China, the rest of the subset increased their relative imports, albeit very slowly. The Russian Federation reached their 2002 level again in 2017 with slightly less than 0.6 percent of imports being 4.0 goods. As with capital goods, import shares do not seem to be related to income levels at a first glance, at least not for our sub-sample of countries. Figure 4.5: Share of 4.0 goods imports in total imports Figure 4.6: Share of 4.0 goods exports in total exports For exports of 4.0 goods (indicator 3.6), there seems to be a correlation with income for our subset. Japan, Germany and the Republic of Korea seem to be the largest exporters in terms of export shares. Again, as a benchmark exercise and to interpret the shares, the following shows the revealed comparative advantage for 4.0 goods (indicators 3.7 and 3.8). Numbers above one indicate imports or exports above the world average respectively. Figure 4.7: Revealed comparative advantage, imports and exports of 4.0 goods The resulting figure allows to conclude that some countries do not yet import capital goods or 4.0 goods, while some others are importing industry 4.0 technology but have not yet moved into a leading position in these technologies which would allow them to also engage actively in exporting. Again, some others are on the way of adopting these technology, yet another group - here Japan - are technology leaders and main exporters of 4.0 goods. This analysis can be generalized to all countries and provides the following picture: Figure 4.8: RCA exports and imports for industry 4.0 goods by income group Figure 4.8 reveals, the differences across income groups seem much more pronounced. While lower income countries are more rarely engaged in industry 4.0 goods trading activities, the import RCA for upper middle income countries is by far the highest while their corresponding export RCA is only slightly higher than that of its lower income counterparts. In other words: Upper middle income countries are predominantly importing industry 4.0 technologies. High income countries on the other hand are much more balanced. It has to be noted however, that among the group of high income countries there exists a small and particularly export-led sub-group of countries (see A) that are mainly responsible for driving up the average RCA export share of the high income countries. In that sense, the information provided in this section may be seen as evidence that the progression dynamics of industry 4.0 goods are currently unfolding within the group of high income countries while they have much more clearly emerged for capital goods and across all income groups already. These first indicators provide the policy maker with an overview of a country and comparison with other countries on where they stand in terms of overall technology adoption and absorption by looking at trade patterns of capital goods as well as 4.0 goods. While Figure 4.4 and 4.8 provide some interesting insights on the evolution of classification patterns of the different income groups over time, one can furthermore derive some clear empirical evidence in favour of a technological progression that is reflected in changes of the import/export structure of capital and industry 4.0 goods as economies growth richer. An additional discussion on these fundamentals is offered in Appendix I 4.1.3 Adoption dynamics within the industry 4.0 goods The analysis above showed that, for example, Japan shows a high export exposure in both groups of goods. In order to know if Japan’s success as an exporter is based on a single technology or is more evenly spread, we can distinguish between different goods. As discussed before, 4.0 goods can be differentiated as additive manufacturing, CAD-CAM and (other) Robotics. Figure 4.9 shows the share of imports (in percent) of total imports of a country (indicator ??). Figure 4.9: Import share (%) in total imports The first observation is that import shares are very low across countries with a maximum of around 0.4 percent in 2017. This might not be surprising as these goods are among the newest generation of technological capital goods. However, countries in this sub-sample show an overall declining or stagnant share of imports in additive manufacturing or CAD-CAM. What is more, the relative position of countries did not change from the more aggregate goods above. This pattern changes, however, when one looks at Robotics where shares of imports of robots in total imports are increasing for the most part. Additionally, to study RCA as above, the user can also asses the economic importance of these imports when compared to a country’s production (indicator ??). Figure 4.10 presents imports in terms of nominal gross domestic product (GDP). This way one can show that, for example, Viet Nam imports much more 4.0 goods than the other countries in this sample, relative to their overall production. Relating imports to a country’s production can thus help give more context to import shares and indicate which goods or technologies are important numerically. Figure 4.10: Share of 4.0 goods imports in nominal GDP This chapter provided the policy maker with a set of indicators that have to be used in conjunction in order to understand technology adoption patterns. Import shares that indicate the importance of a (group of) good(s) and their potential to help in the process of technology adoption are combined with RCA of imports and exports to classify countries as being users or producers. Disaggregating the data can highlight if a country specializes in particular goods or technologies or if it lacks some of them completely. Additionally, the classification of countries together with their position in the worldwide income distribution can help policy makers in comparing their revealed comparative advantages to others. This can highlight potential strengths and weaknesses in the adoption process and points to areas of potential policy interventions. SUMMARY: How to use the concept It should be clear from the above that you need to combine all measures to get a complete picture of technology adoption with the help of trade data. To summarize: -1 Look at import and export shares (indicators 3.1, 3.2, 3.5 and 3.6) of capital goods and 4.0 goods. -2 Calculate revealed comparative advantage (RCA) for imports and exports of capital goods and 4.0 goods (indicators 3.3, 3.4, 3.7 and 3.8). -3 Plot the RCAs over time (together with those of comparator countries you are interested in). -4 Interpret the findings by considering changes over time and also compare your country to the average of the same income group as a benchmark (compare Figures ?? and ??). -5 Do this analysis for more detailed products or product groups to see if the aggregate results are driven by specific goods in a particular country (e.g. indicator ??). Section 5 Analysis 2 5.1 Robots and job loss in manufacturing The focus shifts now on robots in particular. On the one hand, one can get more detailed insights into one product group where countries show increasing import shares (see Chapter 4.1.3). On the other hand, when jobs are being at risk of automation, it is mostly robots that come to mind. As Mayer (2018) points out, the manufacturing sector is characterised by a number of routine jobs and therefore particularly exposed to the potential substitution of labour by robots. It is important to note at the outset, that different indicators have to be combined to be able to evaluate the risk of job loss from robot-based automation. Generally speaking, we want to know (i) how many robots are already in use and how fast they are growing in numbers, (ii) how many workers are in manufacturing and specifically in industries that are characterised as ‘high risk industries’. Some countries are lost in the analysis due to data limitations of the robot dataset. 5.1.1 Robot intensity Robot intensity measures the ratio of the number of robots relative to the number of employees (indicator 3.9). On the downside, this indicator is narrowing its focus to the dimension of robots alone, whereas previous indicators were based on a broader range of industry 4.0 goods consisting of CAD - CAM, additive manufacturing and robots. Consequently, results presented in this section should always be interpreted in the context of robotics and are therefore not necessarily representative for the wider range of industry 4.0 related technologies or the wider adoption capabilities of any of the countries considered in this exercise. However, as the ‘smart factory’ is mostly about intelligently connecting machines (robots) and other parts of the production process, the use of industrial robots is a first indicator of how relevant this topic is for countries or how prepared countries are in this respect. Thus, the intensity of robots used in the production process will be calculated as the stock of industrial robots per 1 million employees. If this ratio is increasing, it can be interpreted as a measure of progress of a country’s industrial automation capacities. Figure 5.1 shows the robot intensity (indicator 3.9) over time. The vertical axis is displayed in log-form in order to see all countries in one graph.19 The figure replicates the patterns from above. Industrialised countries, such as Japan, Republic of Korea or Germany already use up to 80,000 robots per 1 million employees. On the other hand, in Viet Nam or the Russian Federation, they range below 1,000 per million employees. In total, with the exception of Japan, all selected countries show an increase in robot intensity over time. Figure 5.1: Robot intensity: robots per 1 Mio. manufacturing employees The picture is remarkably stable when disaggregated by industry (Figure 5.2) to obtain robot intensity by industry (indicator 3.10). Without exception it is the high-income countries that show a higher robot intensity over time. Also, robot-intensity shows a large variation across sectors with the highest numbers in the electronics and automotive industry. Figure 5.2: Robot intensity: robots per 1 Mio. manufacturing employees 5.1.2 Manufacturing employment risk exposure Almost all observed countries above increased their robot intensity over time. Against this background, an important dimension of the discussion surrounding new technology, are the potential benefits and risks of new technology. In the context of robots, it is the effect of robot-based automation. In a similar way to the employment composition analysis in EQuIP Tool 5: Employment Composition, the risk of manufacturing employment exposure stemming from automation can be quantified. This concept is of particular complexity as automation itself is technology-biased and more likely to affect industries (and countries) which are high in capital intensity. This makes the issue of employment risk exposure a particularly multifaceted concept which depends on numerous factors. Three main components are discussed in the remainder of this section. A recent study (Mayer 2018) identifies the manufacturing share (indicator 3.12) as a first important variable representing a threat of job destruction from industry 4.0 penetration. The argument is that the manufacturing sector is the one characterized by routine jobs and sensitive to robot/human capital substitution. Countries with a severely under-developed manufacturing sector, and potentially a more (non-industrialized) agricultural configuration of the economy, are potentially not very likely to expect much automation-induced unemployment yet because of the emergence of improvements in production processes in the medium to high-technology industries. Under the assumption of a well-developed manufacturing basis, the effect of automation-induced unemployment further depends on the industrial composition of a country’s industry. Mayer (2018) identifies a subset of manufacturing industries that are considered to be at a high-risk of automation (see Table 5.1). As he points out, “job displacement by robots in relatively skill-intensive and well-paying manufacturing, such as the automotive and electronics sectors, is more profitable than in relatively labour intensive and low-paying sectors, such as apparel” and that “economic factors are more important for robot deployment than the technical possibilities of automating workers’ tasks”. Of course this set of industries might change over time when other sectors become more skill intensive or when the technology evolves. Section 6 Analysis 3 6.1 Productivity This section links the current debate on technological revolution that is due to the emergence of smart digital technology to macroeconomic indicators across manufacturing industries. The instruments presented in the following paragraphs allow for a simple analysis of the differences in the dynamics of manufacturing industry’s productivity, value added and employment growth dynamics over time. It also proposes a simple way to analyse and compare country-specific industry profiles across aggregates and over time and furthermore defines a simple forward-looking approach to identify the direction into which a particular manufacturing industry is developing. As discussed before, the concept of runner industries puts emphasis on the concept of sustained employment growth; a feature that cannot be overstated in light of the employment automation risk discussed in the context of the newly emerging technologies with smart systems and robots before. The concept of runner industries is also extended to that of runner industry exposure which constitutes a straightforward instrument to characterise the share of industries within manufacturing that feature positive productivity and employment characteristics. It is also very important to understand that the classification of runner industries, is derived from average global trends. Consequently, one should note that the idea of runner industries is not a static concept but fundamentally depends on the set of countries and time periods looked at. We will discuss these implications when talking about individual effects . The subsequent paragraphs offer a runner industries analysis for the case of Viet Nam and Morocco. We further illustrate how policy analysts can utilise the instruments provided in this tool to understand the role as well as the aim and scope of the runner industry methodology. 6.1.1 Runner industries We start the empirical analysis by identifying runner industries. Particularly through the adoption of new technologies, the importance of the identification of industries with the characteristics associated with positive value added, employment and productivity growth cannot be overstated: This set of industries has remained at the forefront of value added and employment generation and therefore stands in stark contrast to the jobless or declining growth types discussed earlier; see Figure 2.5. In order to be able to identify the corresponding regime types associated with the respective industry, employment, value added as well as productivity compound annual growth rates (\(CAGR\)) are to be calculated using the following steps: Retrieve data (see Table 3.14): Obtain value added and employment data from INDSTAT. Obtain population data from an alternative data source such as the World Development Indicators. Calculate series: Calculate value added per capita as well as the employment-population ratio.22 For the value added series it is necessary to eliminate any potential price effects in the series (see Appendix E for more details). Calculate productivity series as23: \[ Productivity = Value~added~per~capita / Employent~population~ratio \] Calculate the compound annual growth rate (CAGR) for each of the three variables Do this by calculating: \[ CAGR = \frac{End~value}{Initial~value}^{1/no.~of~years} -1 \] Calculate averages of the CAGRs of value added, employment and productivities for the aggregates of interest. In our case we are interested in: the global runners (taking averages of the growth rates across all countries); the income group runners (averages across all countries belonging to the same income group as Viet Nam and Morocco, i.e. lower-middle income; the runners for Viet Nam and Morocco exclusively. For the remainder of this section we will refer to global/income group and/Morocco and or Viet Nam runners as the set of runner industries that have been identified for each of the separate aggregates, respectively. The indicators obtained through this procedure form the basis of the subsequent analysis. It also highlighted the importance of assessing an industry performance in the context of the variation across countries. While this may serve as an important step to learn about the dynamics of a particular (set of) industry(ies) of a country, it says very little about the characteristics of the manufacturing industry of a particular country as a whole. Consequently, and in order to assess the degree to which a country’s manufacturing sector is comprised of industries with a certain set of characteristics (like the ones described by the characterisation of runner industries), a simple ratio of runner industries in total manufacturing is proposed. To this end we refer to the global-/income group-/country runner exposure when evaluating the share of industries that have been identified as runners on the global/income group-/country-level relative to the share of all manufacturing industries, respectively. In this way we can obtain two simple indicators that allow us to assess the share of manufacturing industries in an economy that have experienced inclusive and sustained growth in the past. If, for example, the share of runner industries in total manufacturing of a country is very low, this may indicate higher risk of jobless growth in the wake of technological adoptions which would deserve attention from the policy makers especially in terms of measures for employment protection. SUMMARY To conclude, in this section we have applied the concept of runner industries to identify growth dynamics. We follow the example of the Vietnamese manufacturing industries and related them to more general dynamics observed amongst the set of lower middle-income countries. The analysis has further highlighted the fact that the concept of runner industries is relative and therefore sensitive to the choice of data sample. Whereas this certainly makes the concept of runner industries a challenging instrument to apply, it also constitutes its biggest advantage over more static classifications: Following the notion that there is no ‘one-size-fits-all’ approach to manufacturing policy in general and technology adoption in particular, the runner industries framework allows for a flexible identification of growth enhancing (in the context of value added and employment creation) identification and classification of industries which can be tailored and streamlined to follow the particular assessment needs of policy makers. At the same time, the runner instrument has also highlighted that even within a narrowly defined window of analysis, differences in the respective growth rates are reflective of country-specific effects and should therefore be given close consideration during the interpretation stage of the runner industry assessment. For a careful consideration of the runner industry classification in the case of Viet Nam it is important to contextualize the differences identified vis-à-vis the group of lower-middle income countries as well as the world trend. By and large Viet Nam can be characterized by reporting a disproportionally high contribution of employment-led industries (where positive employment growth out-paces value added growth thereby leading to a negative productivity growth rate). Vietnamese policy makers should be aware of these dynamics as they may bring about important ramifications particularly in the context of the adoption of new technologies. References

C Justification of runner exposure analysis

C Justification of runner exposure analysis The identification of runner industries offers a new way to highlight favourable industry-related performance patterns. Given the characteristics of a runner industry, i.e. a positive productivity, value added and employment growth rate, a high share of runner industries in total manufacturing of a country implies that, on average, a country’s manufacturing sector displays favourable productivity growth dynamics while also upholding employment growth; both of which are highly desirable outcomes. The idea of having a high share of runner industries in total manufacturing of the economy therefore stands to reason as it imposes an interesting enigma: The higher the share of industries that have grown over time, the higher your economic output. Yet, it is not opposed to the often times pursued goal of having a high share of medium-high technology industries forming the backbone of a sustainably developing manufacturing sector. This is because of the following two reasons: First of all, the overlap between the concept of medium-high technology industries and that of runners is substantial: the majority of identified runner industries belong to the group of medium-high technology industries; see ??. For the post-2000 sample, this increases to six out of seven industries. In this sense, the overlap created through the empirical identification of runner industries can be understood as a confirmation of the positive effect of technological advancements in manufacturing that can also be employment enhancing. Secondly, the concept of runner industries adds an additional layer of dynamism to the process as it enables one to capture within-industry structural change dynamics. Because of its dynamic nature, the concept of runner industries offers a gateway to an organic identification of newly emerging trends in manufacturing development: It allows for the possibility to capture the productivity and employment dynamics of an industry which may in fact transition from a low to medium-high technology configuration as a consequence of its adoption of new technology. This transition may then be accompanied by an increase in both productivity as well as employment demanding a particular and novel skill set. Whereas such dynamics can be unveiled using the concept of runner industries, it would remain hidden with the fixed classification of technology groups. Nonetheless, it goes without saying that the concept of runner industries should not be seen as a competing but rather a complementing measure when it comes to identifying favourable manufacturing sector compositions and should not replace the existing technology-centred paradigm. If, for example, the share of runner industries in total manufacturing of a country is very low, this may indicate higher risk of jobless growth in the wake of technological adoptions which would deserve attention from the policy makers especially in terms of measures for employment protection. We have also seen in previous sections that in the long term a higher and prolonged exposure towards sectors which on average are not the best performers in terms of jobs creation may be associated with lower income levels. What is more, the concept of runner exposure may be useful not only in order to summarize the performance of one particular country, it can also be used to produce country rankings based on either the runner share in total manufacturing value added or employment, respectively. E Deflation of nominal value added series

E Deflation of nominal value added series Deflation, i.e. eliminating the effect of inflation, of the value added series is a necessary intermediate step as high growth rates of nominal value added might be the consequence of strong price increases (inflation). Consequently, nominal value added growth rates might wrongfully indicate an increase in productivity even though the effect is actually only driven by the variation in prices over time. Consequently, these price effects have to be eliminated from the nominal value added series. This is done by deflating the nominal value added sequences in order to obtain their real value added representation. For the purpose of this analysis we construct real value added sequences based on the methodology proposed in Haraguchi and Amann (2019) which is calculated as \[ rVA_{ist} = nVA_{ist} \times Deflator_{ist} \] \[ Deflator_{ist} = \frac{nGO_{bst}}{nGO_{ist}} \times IIP_{ist} \] where \(nVA\), \(rVA\) denotes nominal and real value added in period \(t\), sector \(s\) and country \(i\), respectively. The \(Deflator\) is given by the ratio of nominal gross output (\(nGO\)) in the base year \(b\) relative to nominal gross output in period \(t\) and its corresponding Industrial Index of Production (IIP). The benefit of calculating real value added in this form is that it allows for the creation of an industry-specific deflator across countries, thereby facilitating the construction of comparative measures which is particularly important for a cross-country comparator analysis.
